Uh, that's why again I try to focus on agricultural lands because if I can uh uh convince the farmers to use it uh because then by using these rocks, you can use less fertilizer, you save money, plants grow better, then there's more economic motivation for for it to uh to work. meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: You and me. Um and what one of the things interesting about farmlands is that many farms many soils are uh calcium poor, particularly after they farm them. And so they actually need to add calcium and they today they add limestone or many other forms a rock that has calcium in it. And so, you know, what Raphael is suggesting is let's add a rock that, you know, has the maximum amount of CO2 uptake and then the plants get the calcium and everybody's happy.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um it's not there's sort of a similar relationship in the ocean. It's this instantaneous equilibrium in the ocean that's really interesting and that as soon as the calcium's there, it will calibrate, form calcium bicarbonate and you will effectively suck some CO2 out of the air. Of course, the CO2 is already in the ocean, you're just stabilizing it. But but you're you're reducing the acidification of the ocean by doing that. You're adding, you know, a base.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rafael Santos (Guelph)

Is it coming from the air? Is it is the CO2 that's already dissolved? It's it's it's it's hard to say. We have to do some actual tope analysis or something to try to prove the the origin of the CO2 but uh yeah, that's that's the general idea.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines LLNL
meeting_annotations.transcript: But once it stabilizes that once the calcium and the the CO2 are speciated and stabilized, remember that that's now over the saturation limit. This is the way that the earth manages the overall concentration of the CO2 in the atmosphere and ocean by that cycle. And so what you're doing is hopefully just speeding it up a little bit. meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine Hornbostel (she/her) | Pitt
meeting_annotations.transcript: So that's actually a question that I've been wondering for the past couple years on this project is how do we like model the mass transport between the air and the ocean. You're taking CO2 out of the air, it goes into the ocean, you pull it out and then air comes back in from the air to the ocean.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine Hornbostel (she/her) | Pitt
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so my question is, okay, like how fast we need to be removing it from the ocean to kind of, you know, actually reverse the pH before it just, you know, re-equilibrates with the air above it.
